document_type.purpose: To announce and regulate the collection of user fees on a section of National Highway 8B in Gujarat, India, due to a change in the project's funding model and operational status.

summary.brief_summary: This document is a notification from the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways regarding the collection of user fees (tolls) on National Highway 8B in Gujarat, India. It outlines the fee structure, vehicle categories, and other related regulations for the use of the highway section.
summary.executive_summary: The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has issued a notification authorizing the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) to collect user fees on a section of National Highway 8B in Gujarat. This notification supersedes a previous one and details the fee structure for various vehicle types, including cars, trucks, and heavy machinery. The fees are to be collected at specific toll plazas, with different rates applicable during and after the completion of the six-laning project. The document also specifies provisions for monthly passes, discounts for local commercial vehicles, and penalties for overloaded vehicles. The notification further includes details on the capital cost of the project and the process for annual revisions of the fee rates.
summary.detailed_summary: This document, published in the Gazette of India, is a notification from the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways concerning the collection of user fees on National Highway 8B in Gujarat. The notification references previous agreements and authorizations related to the highway section, including the entrustment of the road to the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) and a concession agreement with West Gujarat Expressway Limited for widening and maintenance. The BoT (Toll) Concession Agreement was terminated, and the NHAI took over the section. The notification details the fee structure for various vehicle types, differentiating between the construction period (six-laning) and after completion. Fees are calculated based on the base rate per kilometer, with adjustments for the length of the road section and equivalent structure length (bridges, flyovers). Table 1 provides the base rates for different vehicle categories. Table 2 specifies the location of toll plazas and the length for which fees are payable. Table 3 details the fee structure for structures. The document also includes provisions for monthly passes for local residents, discounts for commercial vehicles registered in the district, and penalties for overloaded vehicles. The notification also states that no user fee shall be levied for the delayed period between the Scheduled date of completion and the date of actual completion of the project. The document concludes with information on the estimated capital cost of the project and the process for annual revisions of the fee rates, which will be published in newspapers.
key_points: The NHAI is authorized to collect user fees on a section of National Highway 8B in Gujarat.
The fee structure varies based on vehicle type, as detailed in Table 1.
Fees are collected at specific toll plazas, with rates dependent on the stage of the six-laning project (construction vs. completion).
Fees are levied for both road sections and equivalent structure lengths (bridges, flyovers).
Monthly passes are available for local residents.
Discounts are offered to commercial vehicles registered in the district.
summary.audience: This document is intended for the general public, vehicle owners, and stakeholders involved in the use and maintenance of National Highway 8B, including the NHAI, contractors, and government officials.

topics.topic_relationships: The topics are interconnected. The 'National Highway Fee Notification' is the overarching document. It details the 'Highway Project Details' for NH-8B, which necessitates a 'Fee Structure and Collection' system. This system is based on 'Vehicle Categories and Toll Rates' and is governed by the 'Legal and Regulatory Framework'.

document_structure.title: MINISTRY OF ROAD TRANSPORT AND HIGHWAYS NOTIFICATION
document_structure.content_summary: This notification from the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways concerns the collection of fees for the use of a section of National Highway 8B in Gujarat, which is being widened to six lanes.

subsections.title: Table 1
subsections.content_summary: This table lists the base rates of fees per kilometer for different types of vehicles.

subsections.title: Table-2
subsections.content_summary: This table specifies the location of toll plazas and the length of road for which fees are payable during and after the construction period.

subsections.title: Table-3
subsections.content_summary: This table details the fees payable for the use of structures (bridges, flyovers) with lengths greater than 60 meters, converting their length into an equivalent road length.

key_information.main_topic: Notification regarding the collection of fees for the use of National Highway 8B in Gujarat.
key_entities: Ministry of Road Transport and Highways
critical_facts_figures: Km. 0.00 to 143.00 and 160.00 to Km. 217.00 (Porbandar-Rajkot-Bamanbore Section)
Fee for commercial vehicle is 50% of the prescribed rate
action_items: NHAI to collect user fee as per the new notification.
Fees to be levied and collected at the specified rates at the Fee Plazas.
Monthly passes to be issued to local residents.
Passes for multiple journeys to be issued at specified rates.

document_metadata.author: Ministry of Road Transport and Highways

road_sections.context: entrusted the stretches from km 143.00 to km 160.00 (Gondal-Ribda section)
from Km. 0.00 to 143.00 and 160.00 to Km. 217.00 (Porbandar-Rajkot-Bamanbore Section)
widening of the existing stretch from Km. 117.00 to Km. 143.00 (Jetpur-Gondal Section)

chunks.section_summary: This notification from the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways concerns the collection of fees for the use of a section of National Highway 8B in Gujarat, which is being widened to six lanes.

summary.brief_summary: This chart details toll fees for specific locations along a highway, differentiating between construction and post-construction phases, and also provides information on structures and their lengths.
summary.detailed_summary: The chart presents toll fee structures for two locations, detailing the length for which the fee is payable and the rate during the construction period and after the completion of six-laning. It also includes information on structures, their lengths, and how they are converted into equivalent road lengths for fee calculation. The chart provides a breakdown of chainage, structure types, and lengths.
key_observations: Toll fees are location-specific and vary based on the stage of construction.
The fee structure changes after the completion of six-laning.
Structures with lengths greater than 60m are considered separately for fee calculation.
The chart provides details on the length of structures and their equivalent road length.
The fee rates are based on a percentage of base rates mentioned in Table 1.
summary.data_range: The data covers toll plazas at specific chainages along a highway, during construction and after six-laning.
summary.audience: Government agencies, highway construction companies, toll operators, and financial analysts.
summary.purpose: To provide a clear and detailed breakdown of toll fees, structure details, and their calculation methods for a specific highway project.

trends: Toll fees increase after the completion of six-laning.
The equivalent road length increases with the length of structures.
patterns: The fee structure follows a clear pattern of construction phase and post-construction phase.
correlations: There is a direct correlation between the length of structures and the equivalent road length used for fee calculation.
trends.statistical_significance: The patterns observed are likely statistically significant due to the clear differentiation in fee structures based on construction phases and structure types.

key_insights: Toll fees are reduced during the construction phase.
The completion of six-laning leads to a change in the fee structure.
Structures significantly impact the fee calculation.
The chart provides a clear methodology for calculating fees based on structure lengths.
The fee rates are linked to base rates, suggesting potential for future adjustments.
insights.business_implications: The data can be used to forecast revenue, assess the financial impact of construction, and optimize toll collection strategies. It also helps in understanding the cost implications of structures.
insights.recommendations: Conduct regular reviews of the base rates to ensure the fee structure remains relevant. Monitor the progress of six-laning to anticipate changes in revenue. Analyze the impact of different structure types on toll revenue.
insights.limitations: The chart does not provide information on traffic volume, which is a key factor in revenue generation. The base rates are not explicitly stated, making it difficult to assess the absolute fee amounts.
insights.comparative_analysis: The chart allows for a comparison of fee rates before and after six-laning. It also enables a comparison of the impact of different structures on the overall fee structure.

summary.brief_summary: This chart details toll fees for structures on a highway, comparing rates during construction and after the completion of six-laning.
summary.detailed_summary: The chart presents toll fee information for a specific location (Km 156.800) on NH-8E in Gujarat. It includes data on the length of structures, equivalent road length, and the rate at which fees are payable. The data is presented for both the construction period and after the completion of six-laning, allowing for a comparison of fee structures.
key_observations: The fee structure changes after the completion of six-laning.
The length of structures is converted into an equivalent road length for fee calculation.
The rate at which the fee is payable is dependent on the stage of construction.
The fee during construction is 75% of the base rates.
After six-laning, the fee is 100% of the base rates.
summary.data_range: The data covers toll fees for a specific location on a highway, comparing the construction period and the post six-laning period.
summary.audience: Government officials, highway project managers, and toll operators.
summary.purpose: To provide a clear overview of the toll fee structure for a specific highway section, including changes after construction.

trends: Increasing toll fees over time (from construction to post six-laning).
patterns: The fee structure follows a pattern of increasing rates as the project progresses.
correlations: Positive correlation between the equivalent road length and the toll fee.
trends.statistical_significance: The change in fee rates is likely statistically significant, as it is a defined change based on project completion.

key_insights: Toll fees increase after the completion of six-laning.
The equivalent road length is a key factor in determining the fee.
The fee structure is designed to incentivize the completion of the project.
The fee is based on the base rates mentioned in Table-1.
insights.business_implications: The data suggests that the completion of the six-laning project will result in increased revenue from toll fees. This information can be used for financial planning and forecasting.
insights.recommendations: Monitor the progress of the six-laning project to anticipate changes in revenue. Analyze the impact of the fee structure on traffic volume.
insights.limitations: The chart only provides data for one specific location. The base rates mentioned in Table-1 are not provided in this chart.
insights.comparative_analysis: The fee rate increases from 75% to 100% after the completion of six-laning. The equivalent road length also changes, reflecting the impact of the structures on the road.

No user fee shall be levied for the delayed period between the Scheduled date of completion (910 days from the Appointed Date) and the date of actual completion of the project, if it is delayed. For the purposes of this rule, any provisional completion of the project shall not be treated as completion of the project. 4. chunks.section_summary: This notification from the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways concerns the collection of fees for the use of a section of National Highway 8B in Gujarat, which is being widened to six lanes.

chunks.content: poses and resides within a distance of twenty kilometres from the fee plaza is Rs 340.000 (Three Hundred and Forty Only) for the year 2024-25 and is subject to revision every year as per the provisions of the said rules. 5. For multiple journey on the highway section, passes shall be issued at the following rates, namely: -  Amount payable Maximum number of one-way journeys allowed Period of validity One and half times of the fee for one way journey Two Twenty-Four hours from the time of payment Two-third of amount of the fee payable for fifty single journeys or more Fifty One month from the date of payment 6. Fee for commercial vehicle (excluding vehicles plying under national permit) registered in the district where the fee plaza falls shall be 50% of the prescribed rate for that category of vehicle provided no service road or alternative road is available for use of such commercial vehicles. 7. The driver or owner or a person in charge of a mechanical vehicle which is loaded
chunks.section: MINISTRY OF ROAD TRANSPORT AND HIGHWAYS NOTIFICATION
chunks.section_summary: This notification from the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways concerns the collection of fees for the use of a section of National Highway 8B in Gujarat, which is being widened to six lanes.

chunks.content: category of vehicle provided no service road or alternative road is available for use of such commercial vehicles. 7. The driver or owner or a person in charge of a mechanical vehicle which is loaded in excess of permissible load specified for its category, shall be liable to pay fee for entering the overloaded vehicle on the National Highway to the fee collecting agency, equal to the fee specified in sub-rule 1A of rule 10 of the said rules, and shall not be entitled to make use of the highway section unless the excess load has been removed from such mechanical vehicle. 8. All definitions including category of mechanical vehicles, its permissible load, category of exempted vehicles, service road, alternative road, etc., shall be as per definitions specified in the said rules. 9. The fee rates shall be displayed for information of the users in accordance with rules 12 of the said rules. 10. Based on the base rate of fee per kilometre for the base year 2007-2008 as mentioned in
chunks.section: MINISTRY OF ROAD TRANSPORT AND HIGHWAYS NOTIFICATION
chunks.section_summary: This notification from the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways concerns the collection of fees for the use of a section of National Highway 8B in Gujarat, which is being widened to six lanes.

chunks.content: ates shall be displayed for information of the users in accordance with rules 12 of the said rules. 10. Based on the base rate of fee per kilometre for the base year 2007-2008 as mentioned in  above, the actual amount of fee to be charged from the mechanical vehicles and the discounts will be calculated by the Authority on the basis of the completed length of the section and revised annually in accordance with the Rule 5 of the said rules and the same shall be published in at least one newspaper in English and vernacular language. 11. The estimated capital cost of the project is Rupees 1815.81 crore. The capital cost is subject to variation as the activities of land acquisition, utility shifting, tree cutting etc., are yet to be completed. The Authority shall maintain a record of the recovery of capital cost through user fee realised. (F. No. NHAI/2018/Raj-Gon./Jet/Toll/Vol.01/F--/D-1116Dated17.09.2021/E-236373) KAMLESH CHATURVEDI, Jt.
